title: The distance between a question and a first answer just got very small
description: Dimitris Papailiopoulos on running research questions through Claude Code: 'I now have something close to a magic box where I throw in a question and a first answer comes back basically for free, in terms of human effort.' The quick signal step - finding out if a question has any meat to it - can now be done without taking up anyone else's time. It's now between just me, Claude Code, and a few days of GPU time.
author: Dimitris Papailiopoulos (quoted by Simon Willison)

title: Reducing cognitive debt with LLM-generated explanations
description: Nathan Baschez shares a trick for reducing 'cognitive debt': ask the LLM to write two versions of the plan - 1) The version for it (highly technical and detailed) and 2) The version for me (an entertaining essay designed to build my intuition). Simon Willison tested this by creating a webcomic explaining his Showboat project's new feature using Nano Banana Pro.
author: Nathan Baschez (quoted by Simon Willison)

title: Qwen3.5: Towards Native Multimodal Agents
description: Alibaba's Qwen released the first two models in the Qwen 3.5 series - Qwen3.5-397B-A17B (open weights, Mixture of Experts) and Qwen3.5 Plus 2026-02-15 (proprietary, 1M token context). The MoE model has 397B total parameters but activates only 17B per forward pass for efficiency. Both support vision input natively.
author: Simon Willison

title: Showboat project: Two new tools - Chartroom and datasette-showboat
description: Simon Willison introduced Showboat, a CLI tool that helps coding agents create Markdown documents demonstrating their code. Two new tools were released: Chartroom (CLI charting tool) and datasette-showboat (incrementally pushes documents to a Datasette instance). These tools help with the key challenge of having coding agents both test and demonstrate what they've built.
author: Simon Willison

title: Claude Code Desktop App shows images being analyzed
description: Simon Willison appreciates that the Claude Code desktop app lets you see images that Claude is 'viewing' via its Read tool, providing visual preview of what it's working on without waiting for code to be pushed to GitHub. He uses Rodney (a tool designed with --help output for coding agents) to manually test pages and view screenshots.
author: Simon Willison

title: The AI Vampire: Agent fatigue and burnout
description: Steve Yegge's take on agent fatigue: If you're the only person at your company using AI and work at 10x productivity, your employer captures 100% of the value and you get nothing but exhaustion. Yegge reports needing more sleep due to the cognitive burden of agentic engineering, noting that four hours of agent work a day is a more realistic pace.
author: Steve Yegge (quoted by Simon Willison)

title: Deep Blue: Psychological ennui from generative AI encroachment
description: Simon Willison and Adam Leventhal coined 'Deep Blue' - the sense of psychological ennui leading into existential dread that many software developers are feeling thanks to the encroachment of generative AI into their field of work.
author: Simon Willison, Adam Leventhal

title: Gwtar: Static efficient single-file HTML format
description: Gwern Branwen and Said Achmiz released Gwtar, a new project combining large numbers of assets into a single archived HTML file. Key trick: fires window.stop() early to prevent downloading the whole thing, then uses inline tar with HTTP range requests to fetch content on-demand. JavaScript rewrites asset URLs to https://localhost/ and uses PerformanceObserver to catch attempted loads.
author: Simon Willison

title: OpenClaw: 10,000 commits in less than 3 months
description: OpenClaw hit 10,000 commits from 600 contributors, 196,000 GitHub stars, and was featured in a Super Bowl commercial for AI.com. AI.com founder Kris Marszalek called it 'the world's first easy-to-use and secure implementation of OpenClaw.' OpenClaw creator Peter Steinberger announced he's joining OpenAI and plans to transfer ownership to a new independent foundation.
author: Simon Willison

title: How Generative and Agentic AI Shift Concern from Technical Debt to Cognitive Debt
description: Margaret-Anne Storey's explanation of cognitive debt: the debt compounded from going fast lives in the brains of the developers and affects their lived experiences. Even if AI agents produce clean code, humans may have lost the plot and may not understand what the program is supposed to do or how to change it. Simon has experienced this on vibe-code projects where he no longer has a firm mental model.
author: Margaret-Anne Storey (quoted by Simon Willison)

title: Launching Interop 2026
description: Jake Archibald reports on Interop 2026, the initiative between Apple, Google, Igalia, Microsoft, and Mozilla to collaborate on ensuring web platform features reach cross-browser parity. Simon is most excited about Cross-document View Transitions (fancy SPA-style transitions between pages with no JavaScript) and JavaScript Promise Integration for Wasm.
author: Simon Willison

title: Elon Musk Predicts AI Will Write Binary Code Directly by Late 2026
description: Elon Musk predicted that by late 2026, AI would skip traditional programming languages entirely and generate binary files directly. This provocative statement suggests a future where human-readable programming languages become obsolete, with AI operating at the machine code level. The prediction sparked debate about the future of software development and whether abstraction layers would disappear.
author: Elon Musk

title: Boris Cherny on why Anthropic are still hiring developers
description: Boris Cherny, Claude Code creator: 'Someone has to prompt the Claudes, talk to customers, coordinate with other teams, decide what to build next. Engineering is changing and great engineers are more important than ever.'
author: Boris Cherny (quoted by Simon Willison)

title: Thoughtworks findings: Junior developers more profitable than ever with AI
description: Thoughtworks retreat findings under Chatham House rules: AI tools get junior developers past the awkward initial net-negative phase faster. They serve as a call option on future productivity and are better at AI tools than senior engineers. The real concern is mid-level engineers who may not have developed the fundamentals needed to thrive in the new environment.
author: Thoughtworks (quoted by Simon Willison)

title: Anthropic's mission statement evolution
description: Anthropic's Certificate of Incorporation from 2021 states: 'responsibly develop and maintain advanced AI for the cultural, social and technological improvement of humanity.' Subsequent documents up to 2024 use: 'responsibly develop and maintain advanced AI for the long term benefit of humanity.' Simon compared this to OpenAI's evolving mission statements.
author: Simon Willison

title: The evolution of OpenAI's mission statement
description: As a USA 501(c)(3), OpenAI files tax returns with the IRS each year requiring a mission description. Simon tracks how this has evolved over time, from early statements about 'beneficial AGM' to current formulations.
author: Simon Willison
